COMMENT: DEATH BY CHICKEN: THE CHANGING FACE OF ALLERGY AWARENESS IN RESTAURANTS AND WHAT TO DO WHEN FOOD BITES BACK
Summer, 2011
The University of Toledo Law Review
42 U. Tol. L. Rev. 963
Author Sydney Knell Leavitt* Excerpt
I. Introduction
WHEN Dennis arrived at a fast food restaurant in Toledo, Ohio, he likely did not realize the meal he was about to order would be his last. 1 He pulled up to the drive-thru, ordered some fried chicken, and went home to eat. 2 Two hours later, Dennis's neighbor found him on the bathroom floor, covered in hives, and without a pulse. 3 Dennis had a fatal anaphylactic reaction thought to be caused by shellfish residue absorbed in the breading of his chicken. 4 The chicken was likely cooked in the same oil used to fry shrimp, an item not listed on the restaurant's drive-thru menu. 5
Dennis suffered the nightmare food-allergic consumers face when dining outside the home. 6 Food-allergic consumers are forced to rely on restaurant staff to provide accurate information about the food the restaurant serves. 7 Providing inaccurate or incomplete information can put a food-allergic consumer at a higher risk for an adverse allergic reaction. 8 Thus, for severely food-allergic consumers, dining outside the home is like"Russian roulette" 9 and is"fraught with peril." 10
Food allergy awareness has become both a major trend in the restaurant industry 11 and a hot-button issue in political circles.
